{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3326692,"name":"kuzey","username":"kuzeyatay","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/59ef9b/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T13:15:34.366Z","cooked":"

we are using 1/2 in hex shafts with wcp sprockets and gears. is there any way of reducing backlash?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T13:15:34.366Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":347,"reads":404,"readers_count":403,"score":1815.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":457709,"topic_slug":"reducing-backlash","display_username":"kuzey","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61536,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/reducing-backlash/457709/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3326694,"name":"Patrick Freivald","username":"pfreivald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pfreivald/{size}/177405_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T13:16:53.711Z","cooked":"

Shims can help reduce backlash.

Sensors such as limit switches that can re-set values at set points can help deal with backlash.

It’s hard to give more specific advice without more specific information.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T13:16:53.711Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":400,"readers_count":399,"score":100.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":457709,"topic_slug":"reducing-backlash","display_username":"Patrick Freivald","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7547,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC Mentor at Large"},"post_url":"/t/reducing-backlash/457709/2","custom_user_title":"FRC Mentor at Large","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3326700,"name":"Stephen Kalogiannis ","username":"sk2983","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sk2983/{size}/135585_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T13:25:55.350Z","cooked":"

yeah, all depends on where the back lash lies in the system, if coming from the gearbox, rather difficult to fix, if it’s from slop on the pulley / shaft there are many different ways to fix it such as a tighter pulley, shaft collar attached to the pulley expanding the hex shaft out to wedge the pulley

note: i clicked the wrong person to reply too

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T13:26:21.971Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":374,"readers_count":373,"score":89.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":457709,"topic_slug":"reducing-backlash","display_username":"Stephen Kalogiannis ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7547,"username":"pfreivald","name":"Patrick Freivald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pfreivald/{size}/177405_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":18265,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/reducing-backlash/457709/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3326703,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T13:43:51.549Z","cooked":"

Shim tape on a side or three of the hex bores does wonders. (Will cut the snot out of your hands, this stuff is amazing, but also sucks)

Retaining compound on keyed connectors with backlash.

Chain tensioners and using the largest sprockets possible for the job.

the sprockets on this shaft are the main problem. also there isnt any backlash on the gearboxes.

Is it the sprocket itself or slack in the chain?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T13:50:25.453Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":257,"readers_count":256,"score":66.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":457709,"topic_slug":"reducing-backlash","display_username":"Jack","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26988,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Alum, Volunteer, Mentor, & Dean’s List Finalist"},"post_url":"/t/reducing-backlash/457709/7","custom_user_title":"Alum, Volunteer, Mentor, & Dean’s List Finalist","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3326711,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T13:51:04.609Z","cooked":"

If you can use larger sprockets, then do. A small amount of slack in the chain results in more angular error on a small sprocket than a large one.

If the slop is between the hex shaft and the sprockets (i.e. the chain is quite tight) then you need shim tape. You may also be able to get away with retaining compound or drilling/ tapping a setscrew into the sprocket hub.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T13:52:57.279Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":255,"readers_count":254,"score":76.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":457709,"topic_slug":"reducing-backlash","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":61536,"username":"kuzeyatay","name":"kuzey","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/59ef9b/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/reducing-backlash/457709/8","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3326765,"name":"Patrick Freivald","username":"pfreivald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pfreivald/{size}/177405_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T14:47:35.335Z","cooked":"
kuzeyatay:

also there isnt any backlash on the gearboxes

There is always backlash in a gearbox. It might be small, but it’s not zero.

In this case:

Larger sprockets, chain tensioners, and shims between the sprockets and shaft will all help reduce backlash.

our custom fix for the slop that was present in our shooter system causing issue with accuracy, this solidified it up really well, may not be in your cards, but something all these lines would help. i would consider drilling and tapping a hex collar through your sprocket as we did similarly quick easy to implement.

back lash removal device1536×2048 354 KB
